Data Science Portfolio Meggi Varnai 2022-03-23 Chapter 1 Poudre River Dishcarge Example Presentation View 1.1 Cache la Poudre River The Poudre River begins in Rocky Mountain National Park and flows east from the continental divide into northern Colorado where it junctions with the South Platte River. Today we can explore the river by taking Highway 14 which follows the river and offers views of the clifs and rock formations covered in sagebrush, aspens, and other native vegetation. But why is it called the Cache la Poudre? The name we know today originated in the late 1800s when french trappers found themselves stranded in the canyon and and ‘cached’ some supplies, including gunpowder, till the spring. “Cache la Poudre” is french for “where the powder is hidden”. Read the full article of the many names the river was called over the centuries. 1.2 Methods The Poudre River at Lincoln Bridge is: Downstream of only a little bit of urban stormwater Near Odell Brewing CO Near an open space area and the Poudre River Trail Downstream of many agricultral diversions 1.3 Data Acquisition and Plotting tests 1.4 Data Download q <- readNWISdv(siteNumbers = '06752260', parameterCd = '00060', startDate = '2017-01-01', endDate = '2022-01-01') %>% rename(q = 'X_00060_00003') 1.5 Static Data Plotter ggplot(q, aes(x = Date, y = q)) + geom_line() + ylab('Q (cfs)') + ggtitle('Discharge in the Poudre River, Fort Collins') 1.6 Interactive Data Plotter #format data for dygraph to understand. can find in 'help' q_xts <- xts(q$q, order.by = q$Date) dygraph(q_xts) %>% dyAxis("y", label = "Discharge (cfs)") 1.7 Assignment This assignment will be primarily about demonstrating some expertice in using RMarkdown, since we will be using Rmds as the primary form of homework and assignments. 1.8 DyGraph example. dygraph(q_xts) %>% dyAxis("y", label = "Discharge (cfs)") %>% dyOptions(drawPoints = TRUE, pointSize = 2)
